classifications.description: Rocking-chair batteries, i.e. batteries with lithium insertion or intercalation in both electrodes; Lithium-ion batteries
Liquid materials characterised by the solutes
Electrodes based on mixed oxides or hydroxides, or on mixtures of oxides or hydroxides, e.g. LiCoOx
Electrodes based on carbonaceous material, e.g. graphite-intercalation compounds or CFx
Carbonaceous material, e.g. graphite-intercalation compounds or CFx for inserting or intercalating light metals

abstract: The present invention provides a simple method for producing a difluorophosphate from a source material, the difluorophosphate being useful as additives for nonaqueous electrolyte solutions for secondary batteries. In the method, a source material containing a carbonate and/or a borate is allowed to react with a source gas which contains P and F and which may further contain O as required. The source material may contain lithium carbonate. The source gas may be produced by decomposing LiPF6. The source gas may be produced in such a manner that LiPF6 and lithium carbonate are mixed and then subjected to reaction. The nonaqueous electrolyte solution contains the product obtained from the reaction.
claims:
1. A method for producing a difluorophosphate, comprising a step of bringing a source gas into contact with a source material containing at least one of a carbonate and a borate,
wherein the source gas contains at least one of a phosphorus compound consisting of P and F and a phosphorus compound consisting of P, F, and O.
2. The method according to claim 1, wherein the phosphorus compound is at least one of PF5 and POF3.

3. The method according to claim 1, wherein the source material contains at least one selected from the group consisting of alkali metal salts alkaline-earth metal salts, and NR1R2R3R4 salts, where R1 to R4 may be the same or different from each other and represent hydrogen atoms or organic groups with one to twelve carbon atoms.
4. The method according to claim 1, wherein the phosphorus compound is produced by decomposing LiPF6.

5. The method according to claim 1, wherein the source material is allowed to react with the phosphorus compound in such a manner that the source material is heated in a hermetically sealed reaction chamber such that the phosphorus compound is present in an atmosphere in the reaction chamber, whereby the difluorophosphate is produced.
6. The method according to claim 5, wherein LiPF6 is heated in the reaction chamber such that the phosphorus compound is present in the atmosphere.
7. The method according to claim 1, wherein the contact of the source material with the source gas is carried out in a solvent.
8. The method according to claim 6, wherein LiPF6 is decomposed in such a state that LiPF6 is mixed with the source material, whereby the phosphorus compound is produced.
9. The method according to claim 1, wherein the source material contains lithium carbonate.
10. A method for producing a difluorophosphate, comprising a step mixing LiPF6 with a source material containing at least one of a carbonate and a borate and then heating the mixture.

11. A difluorophosphate composition having a PO2F2 content of 20 to 65 weight percent, a PO3F content of one weight percent or less, and a PO4 content of one weight percent or less on the basis of the difference obtained by subtracting the weight of a metal element from the total weight.

12. A nonaqueous electrolyte solution for secondary batteries, containing a nonaqueous solvent and an electrolyte lithium salt dissolved therein,
wherein the electrolyte lithium salt contains a hexafluorophosphate and a difluorophosphate and a portion of the difluorophosphate is at least one selected from the group consisting of a difluorophosphate produced by a method comprising a step of mixing LiPF6 with a source material containing at least one of a carbonate and a borate and then heating the mixture, a difluorophosphate produced by a method comprising a step of bringing a source gas into contact with a source material containing at least a carbonate and a borate, wherein the source gas contains at least one of a phosphorous compound consisting of P and F and a phosphorous compound consisting of P, F, and O, and a difluorophosphate composition having a PO2F2 content of 20 to 65 weight percent, a PO3F content of one weight percent or less, and a PO4 content of one weight percent or less on the basis of the difference obtained by subtracting the weight of a metal element from the total weight.
13. The nonaqueous electrolyte solution according to claim 12, wherein the concentration of the difluorophosphate in the nonaqueous electrolyte solution ranges from 1×10−2 to 0.5 mol/kg.

14. The nonaqueous electrolyte solution according to claim 12, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte solution contains at least one selected from the group consisting of ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate, dimethyl carbonate, diethyl carbonate, and ethyl methyl carbonate.
15. A nonaqueous electrolyte solution for secondary batteries, containing a nonaqueous solvent, a hexafluorophosphate, difluorophosphate, and fluoride dissolved therein.
16. A nonaqueous electrolyte solution for secondary batteries, containing a nonaqueous solvent, a hexafluorophosphate, difluorophosphate, and carbon dioxide dissolved therein.

17. A nonaqueous electrolyte solution for secondary batteries, containing a nonaqueous solvent, a hexafluorophosphate, and lithium difluorophosphate dissolved therein, wherein the nonaqueous solvent contains a cyclic carbonate and a linear carbonate and is a solvent mixture of three or more types of nonaqueous solvent components.

18. The nonaqueous electrolyte solution according to claim 17, wherein the cyclic carbonate is at least one selected from the group consisting of ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate, and butylene carbonate and the linear carbonate is at least one selected from the group consisting of dimethyl carbonate, diethyl carbonate, and ethyl methyl carbonate.
19. The nonaqueous electrolyte solution according to claim 17, wherein the nonaqueous solvent contains ethylene carbonate, dimethyl carbonate, and diethyl carbonate.
20. The nonaqueous electrolyte solution according to claim 17, wherein the nonaqueous solvent contains ethylene carbonate, dimethyl carbonate, and ethyl methyl carbonate.

21. A nonaqueous electrolyte secondary battery comprising a nonaqueous electrolyte solution, a negative electrode that can be inserted and deserted lithium ions, and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte solution is as specified in claim 12.

22. A nonaqueous electrolyte secondary battery comprising a nonaqueous electrolyte solution, a negative electrode that can be inserted and deserted lithium ions, and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte solution is as specified in claim 15.

23. A nonaqueous electrolyte secondary battery comprising a nonaqueous electrolyte solution, a negative electrode that can be inserted and deserted lithium ions, and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte solution is as specified in claim 16.

24. A nonaqueous electrolyte secondary battery comprising a nonaqueous electrolyte solution, a negative electrode that can be inserted and deserted lithium ions, and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte solution is as specified in claim 17.

25. A nonaqueous electrolyte secondary battery comprising a nonaqueous electrolyte solution, a negative electrode that can be inserted and deserted lithium ions, and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte solution is as specified in claim 12 and at least one of the following conditions is satisfied:
(i) the sum of the electrode areas of the positive electrode is 20 times or more greater than the surface area of a cover of the secondary battery; (ii) the secondary battery has a direct current resistance of less than ten milliohms (mΩ); and (iii) the electrical capacity of a battery cell housed in a battery cover of the secondary battery is three ampere-hours (Ah) or more.

26. A nonaqueous electrolyte secondary battery comprising a nonaqueous electrolyte solution, a negative electrode that can be inserted and deserted lithium ions, and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte solution is as specified in claim 15 and at least one of the following conditions is satisfied:
(i) the sum of the electrode areas of the positive electrode is 20 times or more greater than the surface area of a cover of the secondary battery; (ii) the secondary battery has a direct current resistance of less than ten milliohms (mΩ); and (iii) the electrical capacity of a battery cell housed in a battery cover of the secondary battery is three ampere-hours (Ah) or more.

27. A nonaqueous electrolyte secondary battery comprising a nonaqueous electrolyte solution, a negative electrode that can be inserted and deserted lithium ions, and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte solution is as specified in claim 16 and at least one of the following conditions is satisfied:
(i) the sum of the electrode areas of the positive electrode is 20 times or more greater than the surface area of a cover of the secondary battery; (ii) the secondary battery has a direct current resistance of less than ten milliohms (mΩ); and (iii) the electrical capacity of a battery cell housed in a battery cover of the secondary battery is three ampere-hours (Ah) or more.

28. A nonaqueous electrolyte secondary battery comprising a nonaqueous electrolyte solution, a negative electrode that can be inserted and deserted lithium ions, and a positive electrode, wherein the nonaqueous electrolyte solution is as specified in claim 17 and at least one of the following conditions is satisfied:
(i) the sum of the electrode areas of the positive electrode is 20 times or more greater than the surface area of a cover of the secondary battery; (ii) the secondary battery has a direct current resistance of less than ten milliohms (mΩ); and (iii) the electrical capacity of a battery cell housed in a battery cover of the secondary battery is three ampere-hours (Ah) or more.
